name: List.Nonempty

types.name: Nonempty
types.comment:
The Nonempty type. If you have both a head and tail, you can construct a
nonempty list directly. Otherwise use the helpers below instead.

values.comment:
Infix cons. Note that you cannot use this for pattern matching. Be sure to add `exposing ((:::))` to your import.

    4 ::: Nonempty 3 [2,1] == Nonempty 4 [3,2,1]

Note: the infix associativity and precedence are not set for this operator, because doing so can cause
[conflicts](https://github.com/elm-lang/elm-compiler/issues/1096) that are hard to work around. In most cases this
shouldn't matter.

values.name: all
values.comment: Determine if all elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Map over an arbitrary number of nonempty lists.

    map2 (,) xs ys == map (,) xs  |> andMap ys
    head (map (,,) xs |> andMap ys |> andMap zs) == (head xs, head ys, head zs)
values.type: List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty (a -> b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: any
values.comment: Determine if any elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: append
values.comment: Append two nonempty lists together. `(++)` is _not_ supported.
values.type: List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: concat
values.comment: Flatten a nonempty list of nonempty lists into a single nonempty list.

values.name: concatMap
values.comment:
Map a given function onto a nonempty list and flatten the resulting nonempty lists. If you're chaining, you can
define `andThen = flip concatMap`.
values.type: (a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: cons
values.comment: Add another element as the head of the list, pushing the previous head to the tail.

values.name: dedup
values.comment:
Remove _adjacent_ duplicate elements from the nonempty list.

    dedup (Nonempty 1 [2, 2, 1]) == Nonempty 1 [2, 1]

values.name: dropTail
values.comment: Replace the tail with the empty list while leaving the head alone.

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter a nonempty list. If all values are filtered out, return the singleton list containing the default value
provided. If any value is retained, the default value is not used. If you want to deal with a Maybe instead, use
`toList >> List.filter yourPredicate >> fromList`.

    filter isEven 0 (Nonempty 7 [2, 5]) == fromElement 2
    filter isEven 0 (Nonempty 7 []) == fromElement 0
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Reduce a nonempty list from the left with a base case.

    foldl (++) "" (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == "cba"
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> b

values.name: foldl1
values.comment:
Reduce a nonempty list from the left _without_ a base case. As per Elm convention, the first argument is the current
element and the second argument is the accumulated value. The function is first invoked on the _second_ element, using
the first element as the accumulated value, except for singleton lists in which has the head is returned.

    foldl1 (++) (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == "cba"
    foldl1 (++) (fromElement "a") == "a"

    findMe = 42
    minimizeMe n = abs (n-findMe)
    nearest = foldl1 (\a b -> if minimizeMe a < minimizeMe b then a else b) (Nonempty 10 [20,30,40,50,60])
    nearest == 40

values.name: fromElement
values.comment: Create a singleton list with the given element.

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Create a nonempty list from an ordinary list, failing on the empty list.

values.name: get
values.comment:
Get the item at the specified index. The head has index 0. Indices are modulused by the length so out-of-range
errors can't happen. This means that negative indices are supported, e.g. -1 to get the last element.

values.name: head
values.comment: Return the head of the list.

values.name: indexedMap
values.comment: Same as `map` but the function is also applied to the index of each element (starting at zero).
values.type: (Int -> a -> b) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: isSingleton
values.comment: Determine if the nonempty list has exactly one element.

values.name: length
values.comment: Find the length of the nonempty list.

values.name: map
values.comment: Map a function over a nonempty list.

values.name: map2
values.comment: Map a function over two nonempty lists.
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty c

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if an element is present in the nonempty list.

values.name: pop
values.comment:
Pop and discard the head, or do nothing for a singleton list. Useful if you
want to exhaust a list but hang on to the last item indefinitely.

    pop (Nonempty 3 [2,1]) == Nonempty 2 [1]
    pop (Nonempty 1 []) == Nonempty 1 []

values.name: replaceHead
values.comment: Exchange the head element while leaving the tail alone.

values.name: replaceTail
values.comment: Exchange the tail for another while leaving the head alone.
values.type: List a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse a nonempty list.

values.name: sample
values.comment: Create a random generator that returns a value of the nonempty list chosen uniformly at random.

values.name: scanl
values.comment:
Like `foldl`, but keep each intermediate value. For example, scan addition to create the cumulative sum up to each
element. The head of the new nonempty list is always the base case provided, and the length increases by 1.

    scanl (++) "" (Nonempty "a" ["b", "c"]) == Nonempty "" ["a","ba","cba"]
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty b

values.name: scanl1
values.comment:
Like `foldl1`, but keep each intermediate value. The head and length are not changed.

This example starts with the number of ways to roll exactly index _i_ on two six-sided dice (the probability density
function), and turns it into the number of ways to roll at least _i_ (the cumulative density function).

    dicePDF = Nonempty 0 [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,5,4,3,2,1]
    diceCDF = scanl1 (+) dicePDF
    diceCDF == Nonempty 0 [0,1,3,6,10,15,21,26,30,33,35,36]
values.type: (a -> a -> a) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: sort
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of comparable things, lowest to highest.

values.name: sortBy
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of things by a derived property.

values.name: sortWith
values.comment: Sort a nonempty list of things by a custom comparison function.
values.type: (a -> a -> Basics.Order) -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a -> List.Nonempty.Nonempty a

values.name: tail
values.comment: Return the tail of the list.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert to an ordinary list.

values.name: uniq
values.comment:
Remove _all_ duplicate elements from the nonempty list, with the remaining elements ordered by first occurrence.

    uniq (Nonempty 1 [2, 2, 1]) == Nonempty 1 [2]
